title: Alfredo Sauce on a Budget
content:
!Alfredo Sauce on a Budget

Fresh Parmesan cheese can be expensive, but you can still have a nice white sauce for Alfredo dishes - over pasta, [Italian Mac & Cheese](Italian Mac & Cheese.html), on pizza, etc.

This recipe is similar to [Basic Cheese Sauce](Basic Cheese Sauce.html), just with a different flavor profile.

Yields: 4 servings

!!Ingredients
* 1/4 C butter (half a stick)
* 3 T all-purpose flour
* 3 cloves garlic, minced
* 2-1/2 C milk (any amount of the milk can be substituted with heavy cream or half-and-half for a richer sauce)
* 2 C shredded mozzarella cheese
* 1/2 tsp Italian seasoning
* 1/4 tsp black pepper

!!Directions
# Melt butter in a saucepan set over medium-low heat, then sprinkle in the flour. Whisk the mixture for two minutes, to prevent scorching.
# Add minced garlic, and continue whisking until fragrant.
# Increase the stovetop to medium heat and slowly add milk, while continuing to whisk, while continuing to whisk, to prevent lumps from forming. Continue until all of the milk has been added.
# Melt cheese into the sauce a handful at a time. Repeat until all of the cheese has been added and has melted into a smooth sauce. Then, stir in the Italian seasoning and black pepper.
# Check the consistency of the sauce. If it is too thin, let it simmer for a couple of minutes, until it thickens. If it is too thick, make sure the cheese has fully melted, then stir in a couple of splashes of milk, as needed.
# Serve immediately over fettuccine pasta noodles.

Source: [Alfredo Sauce Without Parmesan Cheese](https://www.foxvalleyfoodie.com/alfredo-sauce-without-parmesan-cheese/#recipe.html)

# Alfredo Sauce

This traditional Alfredo sauce can be used on pasta, [Italian Mac & Cheese](Italian Mac & Cheese.html), pizza - you name it. If fresh Parmesan cheese is a challenge, try this [Alfredo Sauce on a Budget](Alfredo Sauce on a Budget.html) recipe instead.

Yields: 8 servings

## Ingredients
* 6 T unsalted butter (salted butter is okay, too)
* 1 clove garlic, minced
* 1-1/2 C heavy cream, room temperature (you can substitute milk with some melted butter in it, if necessary - 1 T butter to 1 C milk)
*6.4 oz. freshly grated Parmesan cheese
*salt, to taste
* ground black pepper, to taste
* minced fresh thyme, optional

## Directions
# Melt the butter in a medium saucepan on medium heat.
# Add the garlic and cook until lightly browned and fragrant.
# Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool for 3-5 minutes.
# Pour in the room temperature heavy cream. Whisk until combined.
# Once the cream is fully combined, place the pan back on the stove over low heat. Do not let the sauce come to a boil - keep it over low heat.
# Add the grated cheese and continually whisk the sauce together until the cheese is completely melted and evenly combined.
# Taste and season with salt, pepper, and thyme.
# Serve or use immediately.

# Baked Egg Muffins

Time: 40 minutes
Servings: 4 (2 muffins per person)

## Ingredients:
* 1-1/2 C cherry tomatoes, halved
* 2 oz. feta cheese, cubed or crumbled
* 6 large eggs
* 1/4 t salt
* ground pepper to taste
* fresh basil, thinly sliced (for garnish)

## Directions:
# Preheat oven to 325°F. Coat 8 muffin-tin cups with cooking spray or use silicone muffin-tin liners.
# Divide tomatoes and feta among the prepared cups. Whisk eggs, salt and pepper to taste in a medium bowl. Pour the eggs over the tomatoes and feta in the muffin cups. Top with basil, if desired.
# Bake until the eggs are set, 20 to 25 minutes. Let cool in the pan for 5 minutes before serving. If not serving immediately, transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before refrigerating for up to 4 days or freezing for up to 3 months.

## Variations:
* Replace tomatoes with 1-1/2 C of other chopped vegetables - onions, bell peppers, celery, etc.
* Replace feta with other shredded cheese (I.e. Cheddar).

title: Bigus
content:
!Bigus

This recipe has been a favorite in the family for a couple of generations. Originally a Polish dish, Bigus is a hunter's stew and has many variations. I've included the most basic instructions here, with add-in ideas at the end. This is the way I make it...

* 1 stick butter
* 1 onion, sliced thin
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 head cabbage, shredded
* 1 jar sauerkraut, rinsed & drained (very dry)
* 1 lb. Polish sausage, sliced (circles or half circles) - leave out for vegetarian version

# Turn the oven to 300. Place the butter in a roasting pan and put it in the oven.
# Slice the onion and add to the pan when the butter is melted. Bake for 30 minutes.
# Once the onions are cooked, stir in the garlic and cabbage. Salt and pepper to taste. Bake for 30 minutes.
# When the cabbage is wilted and bright green, stir in the sauerkraut. Salt and pepper to taste. Bake for 30 minutes.
# The cabbage should start turning a golden color at this point. Go ahead and add the sausage and bake another 30 minutes.
# Continue stirring every 30 minutes. The cabbage and sauerkraut should be the same color when it's done. Taste it for salt and pepper, and adjust, if needed.

!!Add-ins
You can add any root vegetables, really, and you can even continue to add to it after the initial meal.

* Shredded carrots
* Chopped mushrooms
* Chopped bacon (use it instead of the butter at the beginning)

You can also adjust the ratio of cabbage to sauerkraut, or reduce quantities for smaller batches, or increase the amount of sausage.

For **vegetarian** Bigus, try adding chopped apples or pears, and other cold weather veggies, like broccoli.

Source: Aumann, Mandi; Saidat, Cathy; Marchenko, Anna; Marchenko, Alla; Zalisko, Olga

title: Carrot Cake
content:
# Carrot Cake

### For the Cake
* 1-1/2 cups pecans, toasted and chopped
* 1-1/2 cups vegetable oil
* 2 cups granulated sugar
* 4 large eggs
* 1 Tbsp vanilla extract
* 1 Tbsp ground cinnamon
* 1/2 tsp ground ginger
* 1/2 tsp ground nutmeg
* 1/4 tsp ground cloves
* 1 tsp salt
* 2 tsp baking soda
* 2 cups all-purpose flour
* 3 cups grated carrot

### For the Cream Cheese Frosting
* 8 oz. cream cheese
* 3/4 cup unsalted butter (if using salted better, reduce salt to 1/8 tsp)
* 1/4 tsp salt
* 2 tsp vanilla extract
* 5 cups powdered sugar

## Instructions
# Preheat oven to 350F and butter two 8-inch round cake pans, and place a circle of parchment paper at the bottom of each pan.
# Spread the pecans out on an ungreased baking sheet and toast in the oven for 10-15 minutes. Let cool before chopping.
# In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the oil, sugar, eggs, and vanilla extract.
# Whisk in the spices. Then, add the salt and baking soda, making sure to get it will incorporated.
# Add the flour, and fold it in gently.
# Blend the batter just until there are no dry pockets of flour left, but don't over mix the batter.
# Finally, fold in the shredded carrots and toasted pecans.
# Take care to get all the chunky bits evenly incorporated. The batter will be thick.
# Divide the batter evenly between the two prepared cake pans, and bake for about 35-40 minutes, until risen and the cakes spring back when lightly touched. Allow them to cool fully at room temperature before frosting.

### For the frosting
# Add the cream cheese, butter, salt, and vanilla to the bowl of a food processor. Pulse/process until the mixture is smooth and creamy.
# Add the powdered sugar, about 2 cups at a time, processing between each addition until smooth.
# Once the cake layers are fully cooled, frost with the cream cheese frosting and store any leftovers in the fridge.

# Eggs

Here are some notes on various way to cook eggs.

## Boiled Eggs^^1^^

Personally, I like them soft- or medium-boiled. But these tips will help you get the perfect eggs every time.

Boiling eggs is best with older, store-bought eggs. Some articles recommended aging them about a week, but store-bought eggs are sometimes up to a month old before we get them.

### Directions
# Place the desired number of eggs in a pot.
# Pour enough cold water into the pot to cover the eggs by about an inch.
# Turn on the heat to boil the water.
# Once the water boils, remove the pot from the heat and cover with a lid. Leave the eggs in the water
#* 4 minutes for liquid yolks
#* 6 minutes for soft set yolks
#* 8 minutes for medium set yolks
#* 10 minutes for hard set yolks
# Using a slotted spoon or tongs to remove the eggs from the water, place them in an in-water bath for 10-15 minutes, or longer.
# Peel and enjoy. They can be stored in the fridge for up to one week.

## Steamed Eggs^^2^^

This method works great for farm-fresh eggs.

### Directions
# Place the eggs in a colander in the bottom of a large pot.
# Add about 1-2 inches of cold water to the pot, but don't let the water touch the eggs.
# Turn the pot on high to start boiling the water.
# Once the water boils, reduce the heat and cover the pot to keep the steam inside. Steam them for
#* 6-8 minutes for soft cooked
#* 8-12 minutes for medium cooked
#* 12-15 minutes for hard cooked
# Place the eggs in an ice bath for 10-15 minutes, or more.
# Peel and enjoy! They can be stored in the fridge, unpeeled, for up to a week.

Sources:  

^^1^^ [How to Boil an Egg](https://www.allrecipes.com/article/how-to-boil-an-egg/.html)   

^^2^^ [The Easy Way to Peel Farm-Fresh Hard-Boiled Eggs](https://www.theprairiehomestead.com/2014/04/the-easy-way-to-peel-farm-fresh-hard-boiled-eggs.html#:~:text=Paula%20M%20says,2016%20at%207:42%20am.html), The Prairie Homestead

Elsie Florence Stadtler was born on May 25, 1920. She married Otto Arthur Saidat in May of 1939. Their first son, Richard Burton Saidat was born in July 1939. Next came Donald Arthur Saidat in February 1943. Finally, twins David Ray and Dennis Jay Saidat were born on 25 July 1956.

title: Gravy
content:
# Gravy

Many sauces use a similar formula. What makes them different is what you put in it. The basic formula for any sauce is:

* 1 T fat
* 1 T starch (flour or cornstarch, usually)
* 1 C liquid

You melt the fat, stir in the starch and cook it a little, then gradually whisk in the liquid. You can make it thicker by increasing the fat and starch. You make it thinner by increasing the liquid. Here are the details for a good gravy.

## Ingredients
* 1 T fat - you can use fat from cooking the meat, oil, or butter
* 1 T starch
** flour makes it opaque in color
** cornstarch makes it clear looking
* 1 C broth - this can be dripping from the cooking pan, broth from a box, soup broth, or bouillon broth
* seasoning - this will vary depending on the purpose and flavor profile of your dish
** If using broth from a box or bouillon, you may want to skip any salt

## Directions if using flour
# Heat the fat in a sauce pan.
# Sprinkle in the flour and stir until smooth.
# Gradually add the broth, stirring constantly over medium-low to medium heat.
# Once all the broth is added, stir in any seasoning or herbs you chose. Continue stirring constantly until the gravy starts to thicken and boil.
# As soon as it starts boiling, start a countdown for one minute. Continue stirring until time is up. Your gravy is done.

## Directions if using cornstarch
# Heat the fat in a sauce pan.
# Slowly add in the liquid and cook until heated through, stirring frequently.
# Combine the cornstarch with 1 T water and stir well.
# Once the broth comes to a boil, pour in the cornstarch slurry while stirring constantly.
# Keep stirring until the gravy thickens - it should take about 1-2 minutes.

Source: Aumann, Mandi

Alla Catherine Zalisko (Nana), was born in January of 1936 near Rivno, Ukraine. Her grandfather was a Ukrainian Orthodox Priest, so the family fled to Poland when the Russian government outlawed the Ukrainian church. Nana was about 3-4 years old, at the time.

During their time in Poland, her older brother by about 10 years, Syeva, lost his eyesight and several fingers while playing with a detonator he had found in the street. The Germans eventually came and an officer took up residence in their house. When things started to get bad, the officer gave Nana's father a heads up, and they fled Poland that night. Eventually, they ended up in Regensburg Displaced Persons camp in Germany where they met the Marchenkos. Syeva became best friends with Mykola and the rest is history.

After the families made their way to the United States, Mykola, who was waiting for Alla to grow up and finish high school, eventually went to New York to marry her and brought her back to Chicago, where he was living and working. They had Catherine Elizabeth in June of 1956, George Nicholas in August 1957, William Andrew in May 1961, and Natalie Anne in February 1967.

Catherine married David Ray Saidat in January of 1976. They had Amanda Chiristine in June 1976, Eric Arthur in January 1978, Heidi Anna in April 1979, and Alexander Mykola in April 1981. Amanda married Mark David Aumann in May 1999. They had Abigail, Mykola, Suzanne, and Theresa.

* Breadcrumbs
* Green beans, fresh or frozen

# When the beans are done, drain them well.
# Top the green beans with the breadcrumbs and stir together. If the beans are too wet, the breadcrumbs will get soggy. You can leave them separate and top at the table, if preferred.

# Kutya with Barley

Cook time: 1 hour 50 minutes

Based on barley, this kutia also includes frozen berries, cherries, and raisins. Regionally, barley-based kutia is made in the Zhytomyr region, where it is enhanced with wine, in the Poltava region where they add [uzvar liquid](Uzvar Liquid.html) which gives this dish a soup-like texture, while in the Cherkasy region they prefer adding various berries.

Servings: 4

* 1/2 cup barley
* 6-7 glasses water
* 3-4 Tbsp honey or sugar
* 200-300 g frozen berries (raspberries, strawberries, wild strawberries)
* 1/2 glass raisins
* 1 cup pitted cherries, candied or canned

# Soak the barley in cold water overnight.
# Cook the barley in the water it was soaked in for at least an hour, until the grain softens completely.
# Add sugar or honey and the frozen berries and cook over low heat for 30 minutes.
# Chop the cherries and add to the kutya, and cook for an additional 10 minutes, until it thickens.
# Serve cold.

title: Liquid Castile Soap
content:
!Liquid Castile Soap – 100% Olive Oil Liquid Soap Recipe

Please ensure you are familiar with the basics of soap making including safety requirements before you attempt this or any handmade soap recipe. Please view my soap making safety video here and read my disclaimer here.

This recipe uses the paste method for liquid soap making whereby an initial soap paste is made and completely saponified (turned to soap) before dilution for use in pump bottles or other containers. 

!!Soap Paste Ingredients 

**500g olive oil**  

I have noticed that my liquid soap is thicker if I use extra virgin olive oil. I have to do some more rigorous testing to see if this is truly the case, but it seems to be! Any type of olive oil will work for this recipe, I used semi-refined olive oil for the video. 

**156g water**  

Distilled or demineralised water is best (makes the clearest soap), but filtered, sanitised drinking water is also fine if it is a soft water type. 

**104g potassium hydroxide (KOH)**  

Mine is 90% purity. If you have a different strength, you’ll need to recalculate this recipe. This video shows you how I do it.

**104g vegetable glycerine**  

This is an optional ingredient. If you don’t have glycerine you can replace it with another 104g water. 

*Be aware that glycerine acts as a solvent in this recipe and does wonders to accelerate saponification and prevent separation of oils and lye water as the soap paste is mixed and cooked. This recipe requires a lot more patience and stick blending without the glycerine, but it can be done! Glycerine also adds emollience and extra moisture to the recipe due to its humectant properties, so it’s great to use if you have it. *

!!Dilution water

You will need between **1700g (1.7 litres) and 2100g (2.1 litres)** of distilled, demineralised or filtered tap water to dilute this full soap paste recipe. Start with 1700g and add more if needed (see video for discussion/demonstration). Note that if you use filtered tap water, your soap may not be perfectly translucent due to minerals in the water.

You can also dilute just a portion of this soap paste and store the remaining paste in the fridge for later dilution as I do in this video. Start with a dilution ratio of 1 part paste to 1.5 parts water (by weight) and add more water if needed.

!!Other recipe specifications

The crock pot I used in the video is a small one, it holds 3 litres. If you don’t have a crock pot you can make this soap using a saucepan on the stove on very low heat, or use a double boiler. 

This recipe is made with a 1% superfat, and does not require any additional ingredients to adjust the pH of the soap. See this video about my method for calculating liquid soap recipes for more details and rationale.

This recipe is calculated with a 1.5 : 1 water to lye ratio for the paste, however with the additional glycerine added (or water if you have no glycerine), the final water to lye ratio becomes 2.5 : 1.

My potassium hydroxide is 90% purity and the recipe is calculated to factor that in.

The recipe makes approximately 840g of soap paste and 2.7 litres of finished liquid soap. Your yield may be slightly more or less than mine, depending on evaporation during the cook. 

!!Salt solution for thickening

This is completely optional (I did not use any salt to thicken my soap in the video demonstration) but olive oil based liquid castile soap lends itself quite well to thickening with a 20% salt solution.

If you are using essential oils (see below) make sure you add those before you thicken the soap with a salt solution. Many essential oils thicken liquid soap by themselves, in which case further thickening with salt is not required.

To make the salt solution, mix 20g of non-iodised table salt with 80g of distilled (or otherwise purified) water and stir until fully dissolved.

Add the salt solution to completely cooled and diluted liquid soap, in small amounts (a teaspoon or less to start with), stir thoroughly and leave the soap to thicken for 30-60 minutes before checking. Be careful not to add too much, only slight thickening is recommended. Too much salt can inhibit the lather and will not thicken the soap beyond a certain point. Jackie Thompson in her book Liquid Soap Making (ad link) recommends adding no more than 1% salt solution of the total diluted soap amount (for example, if you have 500g of diluted liquid soap, you would add no more than 5g of 20% salt solution). 

!!Essential oils

I did not add any essential oils to my Liquid Castile Soap in the video demonstration, however I usually add essential oils as I decant this soap into individual bottles to use around my household. 

I like to use 1-2% essential oils in my finished liquid soap. To calculate this I multiply the weight of the diluted soap (in grams) by 0.01 (1%), 0.015 (1.5%) or 0.02 (2%) to get the amount of essential oil needed, in grams.

If you would like to fragrance your liquid soap using synthetic fragrance oils, check the manufacturer’s suggested usage rates. If you aren’t sure I would start at 0.5-1% for fragrance oils. A little goes a long way in liquid soap!

Be aware that some essential oils and fragrance oils can dramatically change the texture of liquid soap - some will thicken the soap, some will make it runny. Experiment with small amounts first to see how your oils react with your soap.

!!METHOD

*Please [view the video](https://youtu.be/Q-Ul8NNQZqg.html) for the full tutorial before you start.

#Weigh the olive oil into your crock pot or slow cooker. Turn the cooker up to high to heat the oil. The soap will come together quite easily if the temperature is warm enough. Between 75°C/167°F and 80°C/176°F is ideal. If you do use the high temperature setting to heat your oil up faster (as I do), make sure you watch it closely and turn the cooker down to the low or ‘keep warm’ setting before it gets too hot. 85°C/185°F is the absolute maximum temperature for liquid soap making. Too much hotter and the soap will expand/volcano and will over-oxidise. 

#Wearing gloves and goggles for safety, weigh the potassium hydroxide into a small container, cover with a lid and set aside.

#In a medium sized jug, weigh water for the lye solution and when you are ready (with your gloves and goggles on, and a mask if you are in an unventilated area) slowly pour the potassium hydroxide into the water, stirring to dissolve. Set aside somewhere safe.

#Weigh the glycerine into a small bowl and set aside. 

#Get your stick blender ready and pour the dissolved lye solution into the warming oil. Start stirring and blending. Be very careful to keep the blades of your blender under the soap surface to avoid splashing. KEEP YOUR SAFETY GOGGLES ON THROUGH THIS ENTIRE PROCESS.

#Add the glycerine soon after mixing the lye solution into the oils. 

#Keep an eye on the temperature (see point 1) and stick blend your soap batter off and on between manual stirring, to give your blender a rest, for about 10 minutes or until it thickens to a uniform, thick pudding consistency (see video).

#Cover the soap, turn your cooker down to low or ‘keep warm’ and leave it to cook for 30 minutes or until it becomes glossy and translucent. 

#Test the soap paste with pH paper and check it with a clarity test, as demonstrated in the video. If the soap is cooked and fully saponified, no lye remains and the soap paste is ready to dilute.

#Weigh the dilution water. Start with approximately two times the weight of the paste and add more later if needed. 

#Add dilution water to the soap pot, cover and let it sit for a few hours on low heat. You can stick blend the soap as I did in the video once it is at least half diluted. This helps it along in the final phase of the dilution.

#Once your soap is diluted and cooled down, if you see a skin forming on the top of the soap, more dilution water is needed. Add more water in small amounts until the soap no longer skins. 

#Cool the soap, add essential oils if desired, and pour into bottles for storage or immediate use around the house. A lot of liquid soap makers suggest sequestering the soap for a couple of weeks before use, however I never do this. As long as the soap is fully saponified (and the pH is tested properly) then I am happy using my liquid soap straight away. 

!!What about preservatives?

I make my liquid soap for personal use around our household and do not use a preservative for my relatively small batches. This is a great article on the topic of whether or not to use a preservative in your liquid soap. Because I have never used a preservative, I cannot offer you any educated guidance on the topic. Make sure you do your own thorough research in this area, especially if you are giving or selling your liquid soap to others.

Source: [Liquid Castile Soap - 100% Olive Oil Liquid Soap Recipe](https://www.ellyseveryday.com/ellys-everyday-blog/liquid-castile-soap-recipe-100-percent-olive-oil.html)

# Mushroom Parmesan

* 6 large portobello mushrooms (about 4 ounces each)
* 4 tbsp olive oil, divided
* 3/4 tsp kosher salt, plus more as needed
* 1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper
* 6 oz low-moisture mozzarella cheese
* 1 oz Parmesan cheese (1/2 cup firmly packed freshly grated or 1/3 cup store-bought grated)
* 1/2 cup panko breadcrumbs
* 2 cups marinara sauce, divided
* 2 sprigs fresh basil

# Arrange a rack in the middle of the oven and heat the oven to 400°F.
# Remove and discard the stems from 6 large portobello mushrooms and discard. Brush the mushrooms all over with 3 tablespoons of the olive oil and season with 3/4 teaspoon kosher salt and 1/4 teaspoon black pepper. Place stem-side down in a 9x13-inch baking dish (it’s OK if they’re slightly overlapping).
# Roast until just beginning to soften, 12 to 15 minutes. Meanwhile, grate 6 ounces mozzarella cheese on the large holes of a box grater (about 1 1/2 cups). Finely grate 1 ounce Parmesan cheese (about 1/2 cup firmly packed) on the smallest holes of the box grater, or measure out 1/3 cup store-bought grated.
# Place 2 tablespoons of the Parmesan cheese, 1/2 cup panko breadcrumbs, the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil, and 1 pinch kosher salt in a small bowl. Stir to combine.
# Remove the baking dish from the oven. Transfer the mushrooms to a cutting board or large plate. Spread 3/4 cup of the marinara sauce over the bottom of the baking dish, stirring to combine it with any liquid released from the mushrooms. Return the mushrooms to the baking dish in an even layer stem-side up. Evenly divide the remaining 1 1/4 cups marinara sauce between the mushrooms (scant 1/4 cup per mushroom) and spread in an even layer. Top evenly with the Parmesan, mozzarella, and panko mixture.
# Roast until the mushrooms are tender, the cheese is melted, and the panko just starts to brown, about 15 minutes. Meanwhile, pick the leaves from 1/2 small bunch fresh basil and finely chop until you have 2 tablespoons.
# Turn on the broiler and broil until the cheese and panko on top is browned in spots, 2 to 3 minutes more. Serve garnished with the chopped basil.

# Pasta alla Norma

Yields: 5 svgs

## Ingredients
* 2 eggplants (about 2 pounds in total)
* Kosher salt
* Extra virgin olive oil
* 5 garlic cloves, minced
* 1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
* 2 (14.5-ounce) cans diced tomatoes with their juices
* 1 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
* 3/4 pound rigatoni pasta
* 1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley
* 1/2 cup grated ricotta salata, or Parmesan

## Directions
# Prep the eggplant. Trim the eggplant, then and partially peel them from top to bottom in a striped pattern. Slice them into 1/2-inch thick rounds, then season all over with salt. Set aside for a few minutes to expel their bitterness (ideally 30 minutes if you have time).
# Meanwhile, get ready to roast. Heat the oven to 425°F. Brush the bottom of a large sheet pan with olive oil.
# Roast the eggplant. Use a paper towel to wipe the eggplant dry and remove excess salt, then arrange the eggplant slices in the pans in one single layer. (Eggplant slices should not overlap, each should be comfortably touching the bottom of the sheet pan. Use two oiled sheet pans if necessary.) Roast in the heated oven for 20 minutes, then flip and rotate until deeply golden brown, anywhere from 15 to 20 minutes more.
# Meanwhile, make the sauce. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. In a separate large deep pan, heat 3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil over medium heat until shimmering. Add the garlic and red pepper flakes, lower the heat and cook, tossing regularly, until the garlic gains a little bit of color. Add the tomatoes (with their juices), oregano, and a good pinch of salt and pepper. Bring the mixture to a quick boil, then lower the heat and let simmer briefly.
# Finish the sauce and cook the pasta. When the eggplant is golden and tender, remove from the oven and stir into the sauce. Let simmer while you cook the pasta in boiling salted water according to package instructions (mine took about 11 minutes). Reserve 1 cup of the pasta water before draining.
# Finish and serve. Add the pasta to the sauce and give it a good stir. If the sauce looks a bit dry, add a splash of the reserved pasta water and toss until the pasta is well-coated. Taste and adjust seasoning. Finish with the chopped parsley and grated ricotta salata.

Source: [Pasta all Norma](https://www.themediterraneandish.com/pasta-alla-norma/?utm_source=Klaviyo&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=EMAIL+-+Sunday+9.21.25&_kx=zWsQ3S-K326UIC0LjoBrZfzrWB40qYZN9a74hdyLaDw.RMuL9Q#wprm-recipe-container-37902.html)

Rice is a nice basic thing to know how to make. You can use it as filling, make rice pudding, or a great savory side dish. This is something you should know how to make.

* 2 parts liquid

Stir together the rice and liquid and bring to a boil. Remove from the heat, cover, and let set 15-20 minutes, or until all the liquid is absorbed.

Parts can be 1/4 cup, 1/2 cup, 1 cup, etc. Generally, 1/4 cup rice person is recommended.

title: Sifting Flour
content:
# Sifting Flour

When a recipe calls for sifted flour, the question always comes up, "Do you measure it before or after sifting?"  


According to [American's Test Kitchen](https://www.americastestkitchen.com/cooksillustrated/how_tos/5515-the-right-time-to-sift#:~:text=Does%20it%20really%20matter%20if,should%20be%20sifted%20after%20measuring..html)^^1^^, it depends on how the directions are worded.  


* If the instructions say "1 cup sifted flour", for example, sift the flour first, then measure it.
* If the instructions day "1 cup flour, sifted", then measure the flour first, and sift it after measuring.

When a recipe calls for flour to be "spooned and leveled", you spoon the flour into the measuring cup, then scrape the top off with a butter knife, instead of just scooping it from the container. This allows the flour to unpack and measure more accurately.^^2^^

[Source](Sources.html): ^^1^^"The Right Time to Sift | Cook's Illustrated", ^^2^^Aumann

!Single-Ingredient Masks from Nature's Skin Salon

**Avacado**: Soften rough, drys kin with a mashed avacado. The unsaturated fatty acids of the alligator pear stimulate your skin's own natural production of oil (this is not for oily skin).

**Egg**: Eggs are great for your skin. The whites are very astringent and drying, and the yolks are rich in natural moisturizers. Egg yolks are a major source of lecithin, a natural emollient and preservative.

**Plain Yogurt**: Rich in protein, calcium, and vitamins, yogurt makes an excellent mask for all skin types. Yogurt is easily absorbed into the skin and has super softening qualities.

**Strawberries**: Strawberries contain salicylic acid (found in aspirin), which rids the skin of dead cells, allowing it to absorb moisture more efficiently.

**Banana**: Bananas are great for dry skin because they are rich in potassium and vitamin A. They also contain no substances known to aggravate the skin.

**Cucumber**: Grated cucumbers make a gentle and milk astringent mask. It is especially soothing for sunburned skin.

**Mayonnaise**: [Mayonnaise](Mayonnaise.html) has it all - oil, eggs, and vinegar. It is naturally soothing to the skin, and improves skin texture. Mayonnaise is hard to beat for the conditioning power it provides.

**Pear**: Pears are a good source of sorbitol; other fruits that contain a high amount are apples, cherries, plums, and berries. Sorbitol is a humectant that gives a smooth feeling to your skin. Pears are especially soothing for red, blotchy skin. Apply either the fresh juice or the mashed fruit on your face.

**Tomato**: Tomatoes are effective on blackheads and oily skin. The juice of the tomato has astringent properties that help remove dead skin cells and deep-clean the skin's surface.

# Sourdough Biscuits
Time: 50 minutes  

Makes 8-10 biscuits  


### Ingredients
* 2 cups flour
* 2 tsp sugar
* 2 tsp baking powder
* 1 tsp salt
* 3/4 tsp baking soda
* 1/2 cup unsalted butter, frozen (one stick)^^1^^
* 1 cup active [sourdough starter](Sourdough Starter.html)
* 1/2 cup buttermilk^^2^^

### Steps
# Preheat oven to 450. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
# In a large mixing bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and baking soda.
# Grate the butter with the large holes on a cheese grater and stir into the flour mixture.
# In a smaller bowl, whisk together the sourdough starter and buttermilk. Add to the flour mixture and stir together with a spatula until a soft dough forms.
# On a lightly floured surface, knead the dough 2-3 times. Roll out to about 1-1/2 inches thick. Cut out 8-10 rounds with a 2" cutter (glass, cookie cutter, etc.). ''If you can't fit 8-10, mush the dough together and roll again - just be careful not to work it too much or the biscuits get tough.''^^3^^
# Place the biscuits on the baking sheet and bake 14-18 minutes.
# Serve warm.

^^1^^ If using salted butter, reduce salt to 3/4 tsp.  

^^2^^ If you don't have buttermilk, use regular milk with a splash of vinegar or lemon juice stirred in - give it a minute to curdle. You can also just use regular milk or evaporated milk, but it will give it a milder flavor.  

^^3^^ If the dough is too wet and you can't cut circles, just use a butter knife and cut it into squares. No one ever said biscuits **have** to be circles.

# Sourdough Starter

<<<
These instructions will keep one cup of active starter on hand at all times. Most bread recipes call for 1 cup of starter, so you can double the starter instructions to have more on hand, or you can follow the suggested schedule listed below.
<<<

There are starters you can buy. Some are cheap, some are expensive. But it's easy to start your own.  


# In a clean jar that will hold at least 24 oz., stir together 1/2 cup flour^^1^^ and 1/2 cup warm water.^^2^^ Stir it well. Cover the jar with a clean cloth and a rubberband, and wait 24 hours.
# Place 1/2 cup of your starter in a new jar, and add 1/2 cup flour and 1/2 cup warm water. Stir it together well. Cover again and wait 24 hours. You can throw out the remaining starter from the first jar.
# Repeat Step 2.
# On the fourth day, you will repeat step 2, but only wait 12 hours before the next feeding. By now, you should notice bubbling in the starter. Continue feeding it every 12 hours.
# After about 10 days, the starter should be strong enough to raise bread. You also want it to be relatively thick - it should be the consistency of thick glue. If it's not thick enough, add a little extra flour at the next feeding. If it's too thick, add a little extra water.^^4^^
# When the starter gets to this point, you should be able to feed it every 24 hours again to maintain it.
# Once you have enough activity, you can start using the discard for something like [Sourdough Pancakes](Sourdough Pancakes.html), [Sourdough Crepes](Sourdough Crepes.html), or [Sourdough Pizza Crust](Sourdough Pizza Crust.html). You can also measure off two portions of starter and setup two new jars. Keep one out to rise, and put the second one in the fridge. Be sure to feed the backup jar at least once a week.^^3^^
# You now have a starter ready to make [Sourdough Bread](Sourdough Bread.html), [Sourdough English Muffins](Sourdough English Muffins.html), or anything else you can think of. Mama also has a worksheet on her computer that allows you to convert any bread recipe into a sourdough recipe.

## Suggested Schedule
* Feed the starter at least once a day, preferably in the morning.
* In the morning, separate the starter into 1/2 cup for feeding, and 1/2 cup for proofing. Put the feeder in a jar and cover, as usual, and the proofer in a mixing bowl.
* 12 hours later (in the evening), use the proofer as recommended in the [Sourdough Bread](Sourdough Bread.html) recipe. Add the flour, water, and salt and proof over night.
* The next morning, feed your starter as normal, and place the proofer in the pan for the last rise. If you want, you can use the jarred starter to start proofing another loaf.
* After 4 hours, bake your proofed bread as stated in the recipe.

If you want to find out more about sourdough, you can check out these websites that I go to regularly:  

* [Sourdough Home](https://sourdoughhome.com.html)

^^1^^ Some people swear by whole grain wheat flour or rye flour. I just used plain all-purpose white flour and had good results.  

^^2^^ Some sources swear that tap water with chlorine will not work to start a starter. I have started with tap water with no problems, and I used spring water from the store. I honestly can't say if one was better than the other. The starter worked both ways.  

^^3^^ To feed the backup jar, take it out the night before and let it come to room temperature. Do a regular feeding in the morning and leave it to rise. At night, do one more regular feeding, but put it back in the fridge.  

^^4^^ I have found that sometimes the starter gets a little thin. That's ok - as long as it gets bubbly, it's still active. But if you want it to rise, it needs to be thicker. If it's getting thin, then short the water when feeding it. You can use as little as 1/4 cup.

[Source](Sources.html): Aumann

# Tacos or Burritos

This one seems like kind of a no-brainer, but I wanted to include it as a great idea for any weeknight meal.

For **Nachos**, simply assemble everything on top of your favorite tortilla chips.

* 1 C TVP (or ground meat, omit the broth/water)
* 1 C preferred broth or water
* 3-4 T [taco seasoning](Taco Seasoning.html)
* 1/3 C water
* taco shells or [tortillas](Tortillas.html)
* lettuce
* tomatoes
* salsa
* avocado
* sour cream
* taco sauce
* refried beans

**Vegetarian version**

Rehydrate the TVP with broth or water for 10 minutes. Once rehydrated, place in a small saucepan and add the taco seasoning and water. Heat to a simmer and simmer for 5-10 minutes, until sauce is reduced.

If desired, you can saute some diced onions and green peppers while the TVP is rehydrating, and stir them in when you combine with seasoning.

**Meat version**

Brown the ground meat (with or without oil), drain, then return to the pan and add the taco seasoning and water. Simmer 5-10 minutes, until sauce is reduced.

If desired, you can saute some diced onions and green pepper while browning the meat.

**Both versions**

While "meat" is cooking, warm the shells or tortillas in the microwave with a damp towel. Shred the lettuce, dice the tomatoes and avocado.

For tacos, assemble as desired and enjoy.

For burritos, layer ingredients in the center of the tortillas. Fold front portion over the filling, fold in ends, then roll snugly. Place in a dry pan with the ends down and toast on both sides to seal.

# Uzvar Liquid

Uzvar is an ancient Ukrainian drink made of mixed dried fruits.

Classic combination is apples, pears and smoked prunes. But of course you can use any fruits that you like. Just avoid the fruits that were soaked in sugar syrup.

Uzvar has natural subtle sweet taste and is pleasant to drink like it is. But feel free to add your favorite sweetener. If you have vegan honey on hand that would be perfect.

Also you can make it spicy by adding cinnamon sticks, star anise and cloves. Spicy Uzvar is the best when served hot.

Cook time: 22 minutes; plus overnight steeping

* 5 cups mixed dried fruits (apples, pears, prunes, etc.)
* 3 liters water

# Wash your dried fruits if they have dust on them.
# Put fruits in a big pot and cover with 3 liters of water. Bring to a boil.
# Lower the heat and let it simmer covered for 20 minutes.
# Switch off the heat and set aside for at least 8 hours, or overnight.
# Strain the liquid and serve. Can be served hot or cold, with your favorite sweetener, if desired.

[Source](Sources.html): *Uzvar (Dried Fruits Infusion) - Slavic Vegan*

title: Varenyky
content:
# Varenyky

<<<
This recipe is one that works for us, but there are a ton of variations online, and at least three different types in the *Traditional Ukrainian Cookery* cookbook. I will add them as time allows so you can find what works for you.
<<<

* 2 cups flour
* 3/4 cups hot tap water
* [filling](Varenyky & Pyrohy Fillings.html)

# Place flour in a food processor.
# Slowly add water, pulsing as you go.
# When dough comes together, remove from the food processor. If you're mixing the dough by hand, stir the water into the dough in a bowl until it comes together, then continue.
# On a floured board, knead the dough a few times to bring it together.
# Cut the dough into 4 parts and cover with a damp towel to keep it from drying out.
# Heat a pot of salted water on the stove on medium-high so it's boiling when you're ready.
# Take one section of the dough, and roll into a snake. Cut the snake into 12 equal-ish pieces. With a rolling pin, roll out each piece into a circle, flouring as needed to keep it from sticking.
# Holding the circle in your palm, lace 2-3 tsp of filling in the center of the circle. Dip your finger into a cup of water and wet the edge of the dough. Fold it over and pinch the edges together, keeping the filling in the middle.
# At this point, you have two options. You can make all the varenyky, covering them with a damp towel, then boil them in groups of 6-8. Or, you can place them in the boiling water as you make them.
# If you plan to freeze them, boil them for about 2-3 minutes, then place them on a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper, not touching. Place the cookie sheet in the freezer until they are frozen solid (about 2 hours), then put them in Ziploc bags for longer storage. When you're ready to eat them, boil them 3-5 minutes, then toss with melted butter and serve with sour cream.
# If you plan to eat them immediately, boil them for about 3-5 minutes, then place them in a bowl with some butter and toss them as you go. Serve with sour cream.

Time: 25 min
Servings: 10 meatballs

## Ingredients

* 1 tsp onion powder
* 1 tsp garlic powder
* 2 tsp Italian seasoning
* 1 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce or soy sauce

# Bring veggie broth to a boil and pour over tvp. Cover and allow to sit for 10 minutes until completely absorbed. (A beef-flavored broth, such as the Better than Bouillon No Beef Base, will make these taste more convincing.)
# Add the remaining ingredients and combine into a thick dough that holds together. Depending on the type of flour you use, you may need to add extra.
# Add salt as needed, depending on whether the broth and Italian seasoning contain salt.
# Shape mixture into 1-2″ balls.
# To bake, cook in preheated 400°F for 20 minutes.
# To pan-fry, heat a few tablespoons of oil in a skillet over medium heat. Fry meatballs for 5-8 minutes, tilting the pan to roll them around and brown.

# Vegetable Lasagna Soup

**Serves 3**

* 1 Tbsp oil
* 1 small onion (or 1/2 large)
* 2 medium carrots (~ 160g / ~ 5 1/2 oz)
* 1 large celery stick (~ 80g / ~ 3 oz)
* 125 g (~ 4 1/2 oz) mushrooms
* 1 tsp minced garlic
* 1 tsp dried thyme
* 400 g tin (~ 1 1/3 cups) chopped tomatoes
* 1 vegetable stock cube, crumbled
* 750 ml (~ 3 cups) water
* 200 g (~ 7 oz) dried lasagna sheets
* 2 Tbsp basil pesto
* 125 ml (~ 1/2 cup) single cream
* 1/2 tsp black pepper
* 125 g (~ 4 1/2 oz) fresh mozzarella

# Heat the oil in a large saucepan over a medium heat. Dice the onion, carrots, celery, and mushrooms quite finely, and add them to the pan. Cook for 5-10 minutes, stirring regularly, until slightly softened, but not browned.

# Add the minced garlic and thyme, and cook for 2 more minutes. Then add the tin of tomatoes, as well as the crumbled stock cube and water (or liquid stock, if you prefer). Snap the lasagna sheets into bite-sized pieces, and add them to the pan, mixing well.

# Bring the mixture to a simmer, and cook for around 15 minutes, or until the pasta is just cooked. Make sure you stir regularly to stop the pasta sheets from sticking together. Then add the pesto and cream, and bring to a gentle simmer.

# Mix well, and add the fresh mozzarella, torn into bite-sized chunks. Stir the cheese into the hot soup.

# Serve the lasagna soup while the mozzarella is gooey but still holding its shape. I garnished mine with some fresh basil.

# Vegetarian Lentil Meatballs

* 1/2 cup brown lentils
* 1 bay leaf
* 1 tbsp olive oil
* 1/4 cup chopped red or white onion
* 1 large clove garlic, minced
* 1/3 cup + 1 tbsp rolled oats
* 1 large egg
* 3 tsp Italian seasoning

# Place the lentils, 1.5 cups of water, and bay leaf in a medium pot and bring to a boil. Once boiling, reduce heat to medium low and let cook until water evaporates and lentils are tender, about 20 minutes.

# Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
# Once lentils, onions, and garlic are all cooked, transfer to a food processor with the rolled oats, egg, Italian seasoning,Parmesan (if using), and season with salt and pepper. Pulse until able to be formed into balls. Refrigerate for 10 minutes.
# Remove the lentil mixture from the fridge and roll into balls, placing the finished balls on the baking sheet.
# Cook the balls for 10 minutes, turn, and cook another 8 to 10 minutes or until balls are browned and firm.
# Serve the lentil balls over spaghetti or enjoy as preferred.

title: Victorian Cold Cream
content:
# Victorian Cold Cream

## Ingredients

* 1 part beeswax (ex. 7g)
* 4 parts almond oil (ex. 28g) - you can use other oils as well: coconut, jojoba, etc.
* 2-4 parts rosewater or rosewater hydrosol (14-28g)

* (opt.) 1/8-1/4 tsp borax, dissolved in the rosewater (borax can help stabilize the emulsification)

### Rosewater

#### Method 1 - Rosewater

* rose petals
* tap water

Fill pint jars with rose petals. Fill the jars with water, cover and refrigerate for 2-3 days, stirring every 12 hours. Store in refrigerator.

#### Method 2 - Rosewater hydrosol

* rose petals
* tap water
* ice

Place a small-medium mixing bowl upside down inside a large pot. Place another bowl right side up on top of it. Place a ring of fresh rose petals around the bowls and fill with cold water. Place the pot lid upside down on top of the pot and fill it with ice. Place the pot on medium-low heat and boil/simmer for 1 hour, making sure to keep water in the pot. The rosewater hydrosol will collect in the small bowl inside the pot.

## Cold Cream Directions

Melt the beeswax and oil in a double boiler. Gradually add the rosewater, beating constantly, until emulsified. Remove from heat and continue stirring as the mixture cools, maintaining emulsification.

Store in the refrigerator. Use as you would use any cold cream.

Source: [Homemade 3-Ingredient Cold Cream...](https://www.sewhistorically.com/homemade-3-ingredient-cold-cream/.html)

title: White Sauce
content:
# White Sauce

Many sauces use a similar formula. What makes them different is what you put in it. The basic formula for any sauce is:

* 1 T fat
* 1 T starch (flour or cornstarch, usually)
* 1 C liquid

You melt the fat, stir in the starch and cook it a little, then gradually whisk in the liquid. You can make it thicker by increasing the fat and starch. You make it thinner by increasing the liquid. Here are the details for a good white sauce.

## Ingredients
* 1 T butter or shortening
* 1 T all-purpose flour (white or wheat)
* 1 C milk (whole milk works well because of the fat content)
* 1/2 - 1 tsp salt
* 1/4-1/2 tsp ground pepper
* herbs of choice
* 1/2 tsp sugar, optional (a lot of Southern cuisine calls for this)

## Directions
# In a small saucepan, melt the butter.
# Sprinkle in the flour and stir until smooth. Continue stirring over medium-low to medium heat for about 2 minutes.
#* You can continue to cook it until it starts to turn brown, which is signature in some cuisines.
# Gradually pour in the milk, stirring constantly. I like to pour a little at a time, stirring in between until it's smooth. You can also do it in a trickle, stirring constantly.
# Once all the milk is poured in, stir in your seasonings and herbs.
# Continue cooking and stirring until thickened. Do NOT boil.
# Use as desired.

Source: Aumann, Mandi - I first learned this in Home Economics in middle school, but have used plenty of sauces through the years.
